profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday April 23, 2019 at 00:35

did.abstract: Music and other papers by and about the American pianist, composer, and educator Bruce Simonds (1895-1989)

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The Papers are open to researchers by appointment. There are no restricted materials in the collection. Please contact the Special Collections staff to schedule an appointment.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The Bruce Simonds Papers were bequeathed to the Music Library of Yale University in 1989.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Bruce Simonds Papers are the physical property of the Irving S. Gilmore Music Library of Yale University. Copyrights belong to the authors and composers, or their legal heirs and assigns.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Misc. Ms. 308, The Bruce Simonds Papers in the Irving S. Gilmore Music Library of Yale University.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: In 4 series as follows: I. Music. II. Programs. III. Scrapbooks. IV. Miscellaneous.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Bruce Simonds Papers document the careers of the pianist, composer, and educator Bruce Simonds and his wife, Rosalind Brown Simonds. Included are manuscript compositions by both composers, including songs, choral music, piano works, cadenzas for Mozart piano concertos, and early compositions with corrections, probably in the hand of Vincent d'Indy. In addition, the Papers hold photocopies of musical compositions by Edwin Gerschefski, programs, scrapbooks, and notes regarding performances given by Simonds' students.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The pianist and composer Bruce Simonds was born in Bridgeport, Connecticut on July 5, 1895. Simonds spent nearly his entire adult life at Yale University, although he performed widely. He received his bachelor's degree from Yale in 1917. After further studies in London and Paris, Simonds joined the faculty of the Yale School of Music in 1921, where he taught for the next 52 years. From 1941 to 1954 he was Dean of the School of Music. Bruce Simonds died in Hamden, Connecticut on June 2, 1989.

odd.head: General
odd.p: On title page: Deep-sea soundings. Words by Sarah Williams. Music by "Ayrault". Submitted for the Mendelssohn Club Prize competition. "With inconsiderable success" added in pencil.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Scrapbooks contain programs and clippings from Bruce and Rosalind Simonds' performance and composition careers.

odd.head: General
odd.p: Scrapbooks were copied onto acid-free paper and the originals discarded.
